title: 110_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Financial Literacy for Homeowners Act". The Congress acknowledges the impact of predatory lending practices in the mortgage market, affecting families with fair to good credit ratings as well as those with blemished credit histories. Predatory lending involves high interest rates, excessive fees, and unjustifiable terms in various types of home loans. Predatory lending in the mortgage market includes high interest rates, excessive fees, and unreasonable terms, particularly affecting minority neighborhoods and cash-poor homeowners. This practice strips away wealth accumulated over decades or a lifetime, often victimizing communities lacking access to traditional institutions. Borrowers may not fully understand the loan terms and are not provided adequate disclosures. Home improvement contractors, finance companies offered high-interest home equity loans with high fees to cash-poor homeowners. Borrowers struggled with overwhelming mortgage payments, leading to foreclosure. A joint report urged Congress to adopt legislation curbing predatory lending practices in the mortgage market. The joint report proposed a four-point plan to address predatory lending practices in mortgage markets, including improving consumer literacy and disclosures, prohibiting government-sponsored enterprises from purchasing loans with predatory features, and establishing predatory lending as a factor in evaluations for the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. Various government agencies are involved in addressing predatory lending issues to reduce high-pressure sales techniques and misleading borrowers about loan terms. Government agencies are addressing predatory lending to reduce high-pressure sales techniques and misleading borrowers. More assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans and to educate consumers about the dangers of home loans. Nonprofit organizations are at risk due to predatory lending practices. The government is implementing a grant program to educate and counsel individuals about predatory lending practices. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants to States, local governments, and nonprofits for anti-predatory lending activities. These activities include education programs for vulnerable consumers and counseling programs by certified organizations. The curr_chunk discusses predatory lending practices in home loans, including high interest rates, excessive fees, and fraudulent terms. It also mentions counseling programs and referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners to address these issues. The curr_chunk discusses handling consumer complaints and investigating home loans for possible law violations. Eligibility for grants requires submitting an application with necessary information. The maximum grant amount is $1,000,000, and the Secretary selects applicants for grants. The Secretary will select applicants for grants up to $1,000,000 based on established criteria from States, local governments, and nonprofit organizations. The Secretary will establish a toll-free telephone number for predatory lending complaints, provide information and assistance to borrowers, and coordinate with organizations. Additionally, a Predatory Lending Advisory Council will be formed. The Department of the Treasury establishes a Predatory Lending Advisory Council to advise on issues related to predatory lending practices in home loans. The Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from community-based organizations, State agencies, private homeowners familiar with mortgages. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from consumer protection organizations, State agencies, private homeowners familiar with mortgages, and the private real estate industry. Members serve two-year terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. They receive travel expenses but no compensation. The Secretary designates a chairperson, and the Council meets as needed. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council, appointed by the Secretary, consists of 13 members serving two-year terms. They receive travel expenses but no compensation. The Council, chaired by the Secretary, meets at least three times a year and provides advice on grant programs, toll-free telephone numbers, and coordination of activities related to preventing predatory lending practices. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises on grant programs, toll-free telephone numbers, and coordination of activities to prevent predatory lending practices. They also conduct a study on the root causes of default and foreclosure of home loans, providing recommendations for consumer protection legislation. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The definitions under this Act include the meaning of "home loan" as a loan secured by residential property, "nonprofit organization" as defined in another Act, and "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" encompassing certain loan practices. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act defines predatory lending practices as making loans solely based on home equity without considering the borrower's ability to repay, leading to unaffordable terms and inducing repeated refinancing with additional fees. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury, and the term "State" includes various regions within the United States. The term "unit of general local government" refers to any general purpose political subdivision of a State, such as a city, town, township, parish, or village. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the Act is set at $55,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2012. Specific allocations include $2,000,000 for section 4 and $5,000,000 for section 5. The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations as needed for implementation.
